article: I stood by and watched her and her mother busily decorating her college dorm . Everything was in place , _ boxes under the bed and photos of her dearest friends on the wall. I closely monitored that this time things were _ . I began to accept that her room at home is no longer _ . It is now ours, our room for her when she visits.  I _ myself thinking of when I held her in my arm sitting in a chair by my wife's hospital _ . One day old. So small, so beautiful, so perfect , totally reliant on her new, untested parents. My wife changed from the day I drove this little baby home from the _ . I saw myself differently that day, _ .  The last few days _ she left for college, I touched her arm, her face -anything- _ that when my wife and I returned home, she would not be with us and there would be _ to touch. I had so much to say, but no words with which to say it.  Suddenly she looked up, _ me staring at her, which caused her to say to her mother, "Mom, Dad's looking at me funny." She then said, "It'll be _ , Dad. I'll be home from school soon." I told her she would have a _ year. But I said little else. I was _ that I would say something too small for what I was feeling,- _ I only held on to our good-bye hug a little longer, a little _ .  My wife's eyes followed her as she left us. Mine did not. I _ she hadn't gone. I knew that the life she was going _ was exciting and wonderful. I remembered what the world looked like to me when everything was _ .  On the way back home, my eyes were wet, my heart sore, and I realized that my _ was changed forever
